title: 111_hr4329
content: The Act may be cited as the "James Monroe Commemorative Coin Act". James Monroe, besides George Washington, was the only US President to actively serve in the military during the Revolutionary War. He participated in key battles, was wounded at Trenton, wintered at Valley Forge, and served as Governor of Virginia multiple times. James Monroe served in various roles at the national level, including as a member of the Continental Congress, United States Senator, Minister to France, Spain, and England, Secretary of War, and Secretary of State. He also served as President from 1817-1825, where he achieved notable accomplishments such as the purchase of Florida, limiting slavery expansion, and introducing the Monroe Doctrine in 1823. The bicentennial of James Monroe's election as President in 2016 marks the beginning of the "Era of Good Feelings," highlighting his significant role in American history. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $50 gold coins, $1 silver coins, and half dollar clad coins in commemoration of James Monroe's bicentennial election as President. The $50 gold coins will weigh 33.931 grams, have a diameter of 32.7 millimeters, and contain 1 troy ounce of fine gold. The $1 silver coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. The half dollar clad coins will weigh 11.34 grams. The dollar coins minted under this Act will weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and meet the specifications for half dollar coins. They will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of President James Monroe, with the obverse bearing his side profile image based on Rembrandt Peale's 1830 portrait, and the reverse depicting the Monroe birthplace as drawn by the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation. Each coin will also include a designation of its value. The coins minted under this Act will have a design emblematic of President James Monroe, with the obverse showing his side profile based on Rembrandt Peale's portrait and the reverse depicting his birthplace as drawn by the Colonial Williamsburg Foundation. The coins will also include inscriptions of the year 2016, "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the James Monroe Memorial Foundation, the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5 of the Act specifies that coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, minted at different facilities within the US Mint, and can only be issued during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2016. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price including face value, surcharge, and cost of designing. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins minted under this Act will include surcharges: $35 per $5 coin, $10 per $1 coin, and $5 per half dollar coin. Surcharges received will be paid to the James Monroe Memorial Foundation for the development of the James Monroe Birthplace in Virginia. The James Monroe Memorial Foundation, owned by the Monroe Family, supports education programs on President James Monroe and the Monroe Doctrine. They collect and preserve artifacts from his era, known as "The Era of Good Feelings." The Foundation is subject to audit requirements and limitations on commemorative coin programs. The Secretary of the Treasury may issue guidance for programs exceeding the annual commemorative coin issuance limit under section 5112(m)(1) of title 31, United States Code.
